results.title: Black eye
results.creator_credit: Jack Arnold, Pat Rooney and Pat Rooney Production
results.brief_description: Since being forced to give up his police badge following a suspension from duties, Shep Stone (Fred Williamson) has tried his hand at P.I work. Arriving home to his apartment one evening Stone finds a murder victim, and a killer waiting. Cast includes Fred Williamson, Rosemary Forsyth, Teresa Graves and Floy Dean. Based on the novel “Murder on the wild side” by Jeff Jacks.

results.title: Cleopatra Jones and the casino of gold
results.creator_credit: Chuck Bail, William Tennant and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Tamara Dobson reprises her role as special agent Cleopatra Jones, a martial arts crime buster, who’s fierce Kung Fu moves are only eclipsed by her outlandish dress sense and heavy eye make up (Dobson is credited as her own make up artist). In her latest adventure Cleopatra finds herself in Hong Kong, taking on the vast drug cartel which is run by the evil and aptly named Dragon Lady (Stella Stevens). Highlights from this blaxploitation action film include Cleopatra’s poor attempts at undercover work, a difficult task for a 6‘2 black woman in Hong Kong, made even more impossible by her outrageous choice of wardrobe and unbelievable head gear. Cast also includes Tanny, Norman Fell, Albert Popwell and Caro Kenyatta.

results.title: Hot potato
results.creator_credit: Oscar Williams, Paul Heller, Fred Weintraub and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Hot Potato is the follow up to “Black Belt Jones!” and sees Jim Kelly reprising his title role. Filmed in Thailand, the film follows the adventures of agent Jones (Kelly) who is sent to Thailand to rescue the daughter of a US Senator kidnapped by a power hungry Thai warlord. Jones teams up with local agent Pam (Irene Tsu), together with his regular sidekicks Chicago (Geoffrey Binney) and Rhino (George Memmoli). Jim Kelly who is an International Middleweight Karate Champion choreographed the film’s fight scenes.

results.title: Red dust
results.creator_credit: Victor Fleming, Hunt Stromberg, Victor Fleming Productions and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Based on a play by Wilson Collison, “Red Dust” is a fiery romance drama set on a rubber plantation in Vietnam. Dennis Carson (Clark Gable) is happy in the ‘male’ world of the rubber plantation which he runs. Then one day Vantine (Jean Harlow), a brassy blonde floozy escaping from some ‘trouble’ in Saigon arrives at the plantation. The sparks fly as Vantine wears down Carson’s gruff exterior with her special charms. Then Gary Willis (Gene Raymond) a surveyor arrives with his earnest, refined wife Barbara (Mary Astor). Tensions rise as Carson dumps Vantine and begins pursuing Barbara. Directed by Victor Fleming, “Red Dust” perfectly teams the masculine and feminine sexual personas of Harlow and Gable. In 1953 the film was remade, again with Gable, as “Mogambo”.

results.title: Risky business
results.creator_credit: Paul Brickman, Steve Tisch, Jon Avnet and The Geffen Company
results.brief_description: Joel Goodsen is an industrious, responsible and college bound teen whose parents are going on vacation and leaving him in charge of the house. No sooner do Joel’s parents leave when Joel begins to step outside of his conservative and respectable self. Transforming from a straight A high school star athlete to an uninhibited party animal, Joel invites his friends to enjoy his hospitality, as well as his parents’ liquor. Things go from bad to worse when he meets a streetwise callgirl, Lana, who lives the theories of free enterprise and high finance Joel’s been studying. Cast includes Tom Cruise, Rebecca deMornay, Curtis Armstrong, Bronson Pinchot and Raphael Sbarge.

results.title: A Piece of the action
results.creator_credit: Sidney Poitier, Melville Tucker, Warner Bros Pictures and First Artists
results.brief_description: Bill Cosby and Sidney Poitier star as Dave and Manny, two Chicago crooks who have independently made a bundle ripping off rip-off artists who exploit the poor. But they have no intention of giving to the poor, until ex-Detective Burke pulls a con of his own - he anonymously gives the pair a choice, to donate time to a Community Centre or do time in a federal prison. Scrambling in their off-hours to find out who is blackmailing them, the two spend their working hours in classroom confrontations reminiscent of Poitier’s “To Sir With Love,” with 30 troubled ghetto kids. Cast includes James Earl Jones, Hope Clarke and Ja’net Du Bois.

results.title: The Harvey girls
results.creator_credit: George Sidney, Arthur Freed and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: It is the end of the nineteenth century and the future lies in the wild west. Judy Garland is a young woman attracted to the work opportunities along the great Sante Fe railway. Of all opportunities available there is none more alluring than Frank Harvey’s chain of hotels and restaurants. Making her way out west she joins Anglea Lansbury, Marjorie Main, Cyd Charisse and a great Hollywood cast to become one of the “Harvey Girls”. This opulent and sunny film is a great example of the Hollywood musical genre and features an outstanding musical score by Johnny Mercer and Harry Warren (songs include “Oh, You Kid”, “On the Atchison”, “Topeka and the Santa Fe”). Cast also includes John Hodiak, Ray Bolger, Preston S. Foster.

results.title: Viva Las Vegas = Love in Las Vegas
results.creator_credit: George Sidney, Jack Cummings and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Elvis Presley stars as racing car driver Lucky Jackson, a man determined to win the Las Vegas Grand Prix and triumph over his number one competitor, Count Elmo Mancini (Cesare Danova). The Count is like Lucky in many respects, a determined, thrillseeking ladies man, which makes defeating him even more difficult. To finance his vehicular obsession (and to purchase the most important item - the engine), he performs as a singing waiter, thus giving Elvis the chance to demonstrate his crooning and hip swinging capabilities. The task proves harder than first thought due to the distraction of sexy swimming instructor Rusty Martin (Ann-Margaret), as Lucky faces the prospect of losing love as well as the race. Elvis’ fourteenth movie includes hits such as “The Lady loves me”, “What’d I say”, “C’mon everybody” and “Viva Las Vegas”. Cast also includes Cesare Danova, William Demarest and Nicky Blair. Contains the original theatrical trailer.

results.title: Something to talk about = The Power of love
results.creator_credit: Lasse Hallstrom, Anthea Sylbert, Paula Weinstein and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: The marriage between Eddie and Grace (Julia Roberts and Dennis Quaid) is about to change big time when Grace catches her husband with another woman. Contrary to the belief that Grace is a meek, mild and passive wife, she does everything she can to draw attention to her cheating husband. Her actions aren’t appreciated by everyone however, including her father, a prominent figure in society who is embarrassed by his daughter’s public antics, as well as feeling threatened by her willingness to question masculine authority. Grace takes on the plight of cheated women en masse, and exposes the names of all the cheating husbands and their girlfriends in her Charity League meeting. Grace’s number one target however remains her husband, the only problem is her family keeps interfering which may help or hinder Grace’s plans for revenge, and change the family dynamics forever. Cast also includes Robert Duvall, Gena Rowlands and Kyra Sedgwick.

results.title: Ride the high country [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Sam Peckinpah, Richard Lyons and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Joel McCrae and Randolph Scott are two ageing cowboys who decide to join up together to safely return a load of gold back from the goldfields to the bank that owns it. However, their motives are widely different: for one it is a chance to prove that he is still capable for work; for the other it is an opportunity to make his fortune and retire. Along the way they pick up a young woman (Mariette Hartley) running away from an abusive father. When her life is threatened their desires and dreams must take second-place to their commitment to the old West’s code of honour. Sam Peckinpah’s beautiful film is an elegy for the old West: for the morality and chivalry that guided the western hero, for the grandeur of the landscape before it was ruined by industry and mining. Using McCrae and Scott as iconic figures from the golden years of Hollywood and contrasting them to the violence represented by the new breed (Warren Oates), Peckinpah’s film also foreshadows the tension between American generations that was to become open confrontation post-Kennedy and post-Vietnam. By the end of the sixties Peckinpah was to completely destroy the western myth in his groundbreaking violent epic “The Wild Bunch”. But “Ride the High Country” is a brief moment of tenderness in the western genre, and McCrae and Scott are the last of the great western heroes. The stunning last moments of this film are an emotionally devastating farewell to American cinema’s most unique genre.
